results.headline: An Around-the-World Trip to Ask an Age-Old Question
results.summary_short: “Oh My God?” is a picturesque but shallow inquiry into the meaning of God.

results.headline: Radical Lawyer’s Appeal (and Rebuttal)
results.summary_short: “William Kunstler: Disturbing the Universe” is a refresher course on the history of American left-wing politics in the 1960s and ’70s.

results.headline: Critique of a Critic
results.summary_short: “The Hand of Fatima” tries to understand the ’60s-bred hunger for ecstasy, pursued through music and drugs.

results.headline: Breaking Down Economic Breakdown
results.summary_short: Why Philippe Diaz has titled his documentary “The End of Poverty?” is unclear, because this guilt trip/history lesson is really about the beginning of poverty.

results.headline: Drama of High School, Starring Eros and Anxiety
results.summary_short: “Dare” stakes out familiar territory and, true to its name, strikes out in some risky new directions.

results.headline: In the Catskills, Holocaust Survivors Forge a Bond
results.summary_short: In the documentary “Four Seasons Lodge,” a group of Holocaust survivors spend their 26th summer at a Catskills bungalow colony.

results.headline: Dark Side of Heroism, Told in Four Wars
results.summary_short: “The Good Soldier” is an attack on the military, drenched in blood.

results.headline: Howls of a Life, Buried Deep Within
results.summary_short: “Precious” is a hybrid, a mash-up that might have been ungainly, but that manages to be graceful instead.

results.headline: Single Focus: An Outsider With Doomsday Vision
results.summary_short: A chilling monologue of imminent catastrophe, “Collapse” is not just sobering; it’s a full-on assault.

results.headline: Reclaiming a Home at the Sunset of Life
results.summary_short: In “That Evening Sun,” Hal Holbrook strips the stereotype of the grumpy old man of sentimental shtick.

results.headline: Simplifying One Life, Complicating Another

results.summary_short: “Splinterheads” is a shaggy comedy with more heart than heft.

results.summary_short: “Disney’s A Christmas Carol,” written and directed by Robert Zemeckis, is a branded piece of shiny seasonal entertainment.

results.headline: Even Insomniacs Can Have Nightmares
results.summary_short: “The Fourth Kind” may be humorless, paranoid nonsense, but its biggest failure is its inability to scare.

results.headline: Creating Dialogue From Body Language

results.headline: Trying to Find Meaning in a Bolt From the Blue
results.summary_short: In the wispy documentary “Act of God,” survivors of lightning strikes find metaphysical meaning in meteorological phenomena.

results.summary_short: “Storm” is a political thriller with real-world resonance.

results.headline: White to Colored and Back Again in Apartheid’s Maze
results.summary_short: “Skin” is a fictionalized retelling of the true and terrible story of Sandra Laing, a South African woman whose race was classified and reclassified by the government.
